commentBody: Anyone reading this column should also read Ross Douthat's column this morning. These guys should get on a stage and have it out in public with lots of people listening. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/03/opinion/liberals-marriage.html?action=click&module=Opinion&pgtype=Homepage

1. Irina Dunn coined the famous catch phrase: "A woman needs a man like a fish needs a bicycle,"
2. Ultimately, it takes two to tango
3. What does self-partnership look like when it’s home?
4. ‘How to Talk to Yourself, So You’ll Listen; How to Listen to Yourself, So You’ll Talk’
5. Loneliness is very painful.
6. Humans are social animals.
7. Family is everything.
8. “Ahh! Look at all the lonely people”
9. “Don’t you want somebody to love?!”
10. Trust
11. “What do you desire most?”
12. Consuming media is living vicariously to self-medicate: the modern addiction.
Honestly, why can famous women call it 'self-partnered' while if it were young male it'll be 'incels'?

Funny how straight men never bothered about silly nonsense such as "soul mates".
If I remember correctly that godawful "sex and the city sequel" was about your female friends being your (a woman's) "soul mates".
Now even that doesn't seem to cut it.
What's next I wonder.

Singleness? Okay. 
Self-love? I get that.
Solitude? Can be highly enriching.
Self-mating? Sort of a long progress toward self-negation, imo.

So what happens when you break up with yourself?  

And are we now going to start referring to death as "conscious uncoupling with yourself"?
She really is "the brightest witch of her age" (and I mean that in a good way.)
I love me!
Okay, perhaps. But Emma if your reading this maybe call me?

A column like this needs a quote from Eliza Gilkyson:

I'm a one trick pony
Living in a one horse town
People say I should be lonely
But that ain't what's goin' down
I'm alone but I'm not lonely

My thoughts?  

Just live your life as you think best.  Do not seek affirmation from an other, but do not blinder yourself in the domain of the self-referential, either.  

Stay open to all that may come to you along your life's way.  

Are you doing this?  

Yes?  Okay, then you should know that this life, being alive, amounts to residing within a vast playground.  So; if this you understand I suggest you go and play.  There is much to explore, to do, and your time within it is exceedingly short.

(And if No, then reread starting from the first paragraph.)

John~
American Net'Zen

The narcissism of being your own partner is richly abundant. You also have the advantage of never having to say, "I'm sorry," to your partner. You remain supreme and unquestioned – a tiny little self-anointed god or goddess – floating serenely above the tumultuous seas of conflicted humanity. Still, it must be lonely at the top.
Being your own soul mate only works if you are also your own best friend.
I am pretty sure "self-coupling" is not going to be a viable future trend!...because after the current practitioners pass away..well nothing!!
You should definitely be your own soul mate.  I am.  It was a conscious decision on my part and I’m quite pleased with the results.
My friend Nancy Axthelm used to say, "When you get to be thirty and you're still single, you'e good at it."
Yes. Please contact my office and set up an appointment.
There was a column yesterday in this very same newspaper that claims that liberals do not want to destroy the traditional family. This column seems to contradict the one from yesterday.
“Self-partnered” sounds a lot like “conscious un-coupling.” Empty euphemisms.
"There's nobody for someone"
“What if - what if Life itself were the sweetheart?”  Lucy Gayheart, by Willa Cather 1935
If I officially announce that I am my own soul mate, you think they'll let me stay at one of those couples-only resorts or take one of those couples-only cruises?

"Just do the steps that you've been shown,
By everyone you've ever known,
Until the dance becomes your very own.
No matter how close to yours,
Another's steps have grown,
In the end there is one dance you'll do alone."

Jackson Browne, For A Dancer

Forward, into the void…

I guess we're going WAY back to the drawing board now.
Binary fission, like with yeast, may be a little tough though.  But reproductive cloning will surely come into taxpayer range, like gender reassignment apparently has (according to the most "open-minded" news and its consumers).

In the words of one of my favorite writers, Oscar Wilde:
“To love oneself is the beginning of a lifelong romance!”
Gosh, what did we all do for the past 100,000 years before people realized that we needed soul mates??

No, you can't be your own soul mate, because, as Aristotle observed long ago, man is a social animal. The desire and ability to reach out to other people who are not even relatives is what makes us special (and the dominant species).

If you are not interested in or have given up on finding your soul mate in another, the answer isn’t to be your own soul mate which, no matter how one tries to twist it, is a nonsensical concept. The more meaningful answer is to dedicate yourself to helping as many others as you reasonably can, not to focus even more on yourself.
Ask Emma Watson who she is 3 years from now and you'll get a different answer.  She's a young person who is looking, just like you.

about 51% of the US population is single/self parternered/decoupled/soulmated...whatever you want to call it, and its been there for quite some generations now. So, its here to stay and lets just acknowledge it the way to be. Give equal benefits to single people at jobs, they may not get to take benefits of parental long leave, but the do like to travel.

As middle of 3 sons and runt at 5’10” I was invisible. Yet forced to dumb down to fit in with the slow ones. 

Both my brothers took their wives from me. Literally!

Father kept telling me no, my dreams were impossible. 

5 grade schools. 5 HS. 5 colleges until MFA age 51 after 2 failed marriages. 

Love my stepdaughter and her family. She is 21 years younger. 

Finally self actuated and very happy in retirement. 

Yet wonder what could have been. 

At an event a new friend exclaimed we must find me a wife. 

I laughed loudly out loud as I excused myself. 

Now back to making art.
Dr. Finkel clearly does not know SATC. Carrie Bradshaw may have been an independent woman, but her heart pined for one thing only: Mr. Big. And reader, you know that she married him.

this confused article declares at the start that self coupling is great. but then shows that the right couplings with others are the best way to self fulfillment and contentment, as many survey show. so what's the point, except to say the author wishes the facts were otherwise than they are.
It seems to me that nuns and monks discovered how to be their own partner in life without all the grief from society. They married Christ.  Would you call them selfish?

Girl, get a Dog.  Or Two.
   Seriously.

" If the happiness of the self — myself — is now the highest value, the search for The One seems like a search for someone who will make me The One I’ve been searching for all along."
What can one say? Silly? Obvious? Nonsense? Trivial? A first draft for a bad movie?

So jelly.  OMG.  This would totally be me now.  That is the pinnacle - not feeling a need.  That is fresh and now.  We know all the past...and it sucked "big time".  

The only people who nod to this are the rich white people who know nothing.

commentBody:
What a validating read!  

I decided four years ago to go it alone, including without sex, though I'm only 39.  Everyone I tell this to retorts, "You'll find someone some day!"  To which my eyes glaze over as I remind them that this is a happy choice I've made.

There are many reasons one might choose to be eternally single and celibate, but the one I never hear discussed is:  maybe some people, like myself, are too overwhelmed in romantic relationships.  Maybe some of us really are not cut out for them.  People always say you can learn to be in relationship by working through your stuff, but that all sounds a bit too America-optimistic to me.  Plus, I work hard enough in other areas of my life, and I don't like working.

I decided to forgo romantic relationships when I realized that I had failed my whole adult life at sustaining them.  So have most people I know.  But it had never occurred to me that I could just stop.  Why would I keep doing something I fail at over and over?  

Nah, a romantic dyad is not the only way to love, to express love, to be loved.  Staying single is also not inherently narcissistic:  you can still be a responsible human being, maybe more so for some of us, without partnership.  I'm thrilled to see this discussion finally hitting the main streams.  We need to create more possibilities for love.

commentBody:
I am in my late 50s and have been happily single and "unpaired" all my life. It was the right lifestyle choice for me, whether or not it's the right choice for someone else.

That said, I find the notion that I am "my own soul mate" or "self-coupled" rather ridiculous and pretentious. It still echos the society trope that you're only complete when paired. 

I don't need a soul mate. I don't need to be a couple. Not even if the "other" is myself. I am already complete, fulfilled, and happy.

Interesting story, but in my own life experience, I found that until I became mature enough to be ready and willing to sacrifice all of my own selfish needs for a spouse or child, I did not really understand the deepest meaning of love.  I would hate to get to the end of my life without these experiences and what they have taught me.

No doubt, the kind of love you share with a spouse is extraordinary and different from any other kind of love, as is the love for a child. But to imply that those loves are "the deepest" and that those of us who have only managed to share love with parents, siblings and friends, etc. are lacking the deepest meaning of love is pretty arrogant. It\'s not just a matter of being mature - if only!', 'createDate': '1575321803', 'updateDate': '1577718396', 'approveDate': '1575329780', 'recommendations': 66, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103930063, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'James', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103930867', 'isAnonymous': False}, {'commentID': 103930194, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103930194, 'userID': 74928083, 'userDisplayName': 'sedanchair', 'userLocation': 'Seattle', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\\//>', 'commentBody': '@James Most people do not have the intelligence or empathy to understand the deepest meaning of love, because it involves loving your neighbor as yourself. Only love without self-interest can.', 'createDate': '1575319361', 'updateDate': '1579023027', 'approveDate': '1575329784', 'recommendations': 30, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103930063, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'James', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103930194', 'isAnonymous': False}, {'commentID': 103933094, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103933094, 'userID': 16019737, 'userDisplayName': 'Olivia', 'userLocation': 'New York', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\\//>', 'commentBody': "@James I would take @SK and @sedanchair's responses even further. commentBody: Parents are the key. Was raised by my Czech Grandmother. A child of the 60's. Enough said. That young women and men see the hypocrisy of our generation gives me hope. Much gratitude.

I hope a day will come when society stops using markers like marriage and relationship status as signs that one has "made it". These types of man-made idiocy is what has led so many to dive into unsuitable marriages, leading to years of despair. 

Marriage is also the only institution where horribly cruel and mind-boggling murder-suicides happen. Unlike husbands and wives, friends generally don't see killing each other, little children and finally themselves as a viable option when life doesn't go our way. 

But you don't hear that when old folks pressure younger people to marry. It's brainwashing to think that marriage is the most wonderful thing that everyone must do in order to have a good life.

Missing from the article: the word "talent". Partnerability, like spirituality, is a talent. Most people have some, a handful are geniuses, and a fair number others have none at all.

Why make them suffer?
I love spending time with my favorite person. Myself. And my dog, of course.
I'm never alone. I'm always with myself.

Interesting point-counter point dialogue between this article and Douthat's in today's electronic edition.  What Onishi celebrates Douthat deplores.  If an intentional juxtaposition, kudos to the editorial staff.
I recall a best selling book , "How to be Your Own Best Friend" which in hindsight was way ahead of its time.

You don't have to get married. You don't have to have children. You don't need someone to validate your existence. Life is beautiful. It is not narcissism to see the beauty of the world in your own way.

"In an academic paper on love and marriage published in 2014, Dr. [Eli] Finkel and his co-authors argued that since 1965 American marriages have formed around the ideal of “expressive individualism,” which centers on the creation of individual identity and the charting of a path of personal growth."

The above certainly explains why the lifelong probability of an American marriage ending in divorce is 40%–50%.

It’s a lot easier for successful people like Lizzie and Emma Stone to be independent than it is for the rest of us. The problem in our culture is not in people looking for the one, but in people being too selfish and narcissistic.

Why do I have the feeling that it won’t be long before we read about who Emma and Lizzo are dating?  Life isn’t a straight line. We make all kinds of connections along the way. Enjoy the ride - with or without a partner.

One may not realise that one's partner is The One until  after shared pains and joys and mutual dependencies have made you The One for each other. In short, you just muddle through life as best you can, and then you discover that it was worth teh effort after all.
I know someone who was her own soul mate.  But she gave it up when she realized how difficult and intrusive it is to have a soul mate who ALWAYS knows what you're feeling and thinking.

“recognize that being single and without children doesn’t signal failure.”

It does represent failure. 

Marriage, parenting, starting your own family. I mean, that’s it in life.

I would tell her, don’t wait for your 50s to realize this. 

Work harder not to fail.
Sounds corny but I always tear up when I hear the song "People."
Shel Silverstein described had this notion and depicted in quite nicely back in 1976 in "The Missing Piece"

As an aging American, I get really weary of reading all the ways we apparently need to describe something when one word suffices.  No wonder we can't navigate social structures anymore.  Next thing someone will suggest that the word "marriage" needs to be replaced.  "Hi.  I'm Pete.  My partner (she used to be my wife) and I have been coupled for 52 years.  What about you?  Uncoupled?  Oh, I see.  Self-coupled."  Sigh.

“It’s the economy stupid”.    Student loans, bad jobs, low wages, no-to-little health insurance.   Expensive housing that today silently pushes people out of metro areas .   STEM ( Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) graduates are working on non related fields, though pundits and experts tell us that the new economy requires tech-related skills.   Could also be that women still have to carry a lot of the responsibility in modern couples where a single income is not enough?    Besides working full-time jobs, they have to care for all house work, tend to children, if they can afford them (many can’t)  and so on...   it sounds exhausting.   Not sure it’s about self-coupling.    Loneliness persists which explains the opioid/ heroine addiction crisis.    What would Plato make of today’s fewer and fewer choices, despite so much wealth around us.
Another, simpler interpretation... Women are tired of the unequal sacrifice expected of them in a traditional marriage.

Lost among all this psychobabble is an elementary fact: like all other life forms on this planet we have three imperatives, which are to be born, to reproduce, and to die. Giving life to a new generation carries with it the responsibility that these offspring thrive and that the world they inherit is habitable. Failure to attend to this could result in the extinction of the species — and all “self-actualized” beings along with it.

Interesting article. Like many societal articles published in this paper, it’s extremely idealistic. Seems to be many more women than men can get on board with this notion. The word narcissism immediately came to mind when reading it, which matches well with unrealistic liberal idealism. I’m not perfect and neither is my wife, but I’m so glad not to sleep alone at night. As a hereto man, I will say that lots of hetero men I know are ultimately lame selfish jerks, so can’t blame women for searching out this philosophy.

An old concept well examined, but ultimately having raised myself since age 7, been in and out of foster homes etc., we are all ultimately alone. This "breed" gets things done because we are the only ones we can rely on. Isn't that the ultimate existential thought? Unchallenged minds who never read, don't care and never will care end up being the President of the United States installed by Russia.

“I have been in worse company than my own.” - Me at 22 after breaking up with my college boyfriend. 

“I am currently between exes.” - Me at 63, with thanks for the idea to Jeff Goldblum as Ian Malcolm. 

Serial monogamy is for me, as my evolution and reinventions seem to have been too demanding.
At the close of the 21st century’s second decade, women freely choosing to not be another’s partner is news?
Wrapped up in oneself, is self-seeking, there’s no other love than one’s own love for oneself.

You're less likely to search for a soul mate if you're wealthy and/or have a fulfilling career. For the rest of us, the elusive search for love is both a spiritual and practical quest: who is going to love me no matter what and who is going to help with the bills? In the end, some people simply need relationships and some don't. The good thing is now women can choose without being labeled "old maids."
Of course you can. We hold this to be self evident.

Now that the Supreme Court has affirmed the constitutional right to same-sex marriage,  those who intend to be their own soul mates should consider solidifying that relationship with a formal wedding ceremony.

commentBody: A housekeeper is way cheaper than a wife. The dishes and the toilets sparkle, and conversation, while limited, does not include a list of my character defects.

commentBody:
Thomas Merton, a Trappist monk, eventually concluded, "Love is our true destiny. We do not find the meaning of life by ourselves alone - we find it with another."

The journey can be challenging, but I firmly believe Merton was right.

commentBody: Gave up looking or even wanting a partner for retirement and never been happier. Finally, there’s a me after a lifetime of everyone else.

commentBody: I adore being single, although being in Portland I've gone with "solo-polyamourous"...I have been in every sort of relationship imaginable and I am definitely more in love with myself than any partner I've ever had, so this makes sense for me. I'm too selfish to put my partners needs ahead of my own. It's easier to date people who like to be by themselves most of the time and occasionally seek sexual solace or emotional comfort with friends. I see children, in this day and age, as a hostile gesture...we need to depopulate the planet so that it can heal, not have more kids. I prefer long, languid hours alone to time with a partner or spouse. Coupling was always designed to give the state more power and to rope people into needing large incomes to support their hetero-normative lifestyles. Those days are over. Now we can be whatever we want.

The only reason for the existence of this planet and this dimension is spiritual growth.  This entails having a wide range of experience so that we can know the difference between love and not-love.  Each person is on an individual path of growth so in that sense, yes, we are the one we are looking for, the "we" being ourselves as Soul, neither male nor female, but whole.
Prior to birth we reviewed options and advantages (i.e. growth opportunities) in order to imprint milestones that we will hopefully notice at the right time during our life.  Meet this person, have this experience, avoid a certain reaction, say one thing to change this person's life. These karmic situations and "debts" help us to learn and grow.  When the karma is satisfied, which means seeing the situation for what it is and letting it go, then the connection to that situation or that person starts to dissipate, and you move on to the next.  Again, it is all an individual path of experience.

However, it should be obvious that having a partner to support your journey can be very advantageous, including the endless opportunities to give love and confront your own shortcomings. Some people do this with a cat, but I would argue that a person will reflect more and greater opportunities to confront yourself.

Neither the article nor the thoughtful comments posted thus far touch upon the economic aspects of singlehood. The two examples in the article are women who have plenty of money to burn. I appreciate that successful, independent women were featured, but statistically women still have lower earning power than men. 

I was married for 8 of my 66+ years and gave birth to 3 children with unsupportive fathers, yet all of them now have college educations. Not until they completed college did I start saving money for my retirement.

I have not dated in the 30 years since separating --for various reasons-- primarily because I did not want to go through another heart-wrenching breakup --whether via divorce or death. 

Now I am living very frugally and often wonder if my father was right in suggesting that I remarry for economic reasons. Of course, there's no guarantee that being coupled would have resulted in my owning a home or being able to buy a newer car or even put more essentials into my shopping basket without waiting until I run out. 

It seems another article on the financial costs of remaining single vs. coupling is waiting to be penned.

commentBody:
I hit the jackpot when I was 31. I saw a young woman coming down the hallway towards me and, for reasons I can't explain, I knew she was the "one" for me. 

As it turned out, she was. Throughout our 39 year relationship and marriage we could talk about most everything and we enjoyed experiencing the world around us, which we did, children in tow from the beginning. In short, we learned. From each other and from the world around us. And that taught us about ourselves.

She's gone now, having died from pancreatic cancer 18 months ago. For a while, I thought my life was over. I had nobody to share anything with and without sharing, there wasn't a lot of meaning to whatever I was learning. 

What has come to me more recently, however, is more curiosity. At first, satisfying my curiosity was a way to kill time, whatever time I had left. And then, almost by chance, I discovered others who were curious about some of the same things. And so, I'm back to sharing. Sometimes there are walls too high for some thoughts to be shared, but at my age I'm not particularly concerned about what others may think of me. If they think my curiosity is odd, I think their lack of it is even odder.

I would find it hard to find fulfillment alone. Thankfully, I'm finding it in other places besides marriage.

commentBody: I’m self-partnered despite my best efforts to attract a partner.  Lots of false starts, first dates, and near-misses but at 54 it appears that not everyone is destined to have a partner.  I find it a bit irritating to read others comments that imply that self-partnering is some kind of narcissistic fad.  For some of us, it’s just life.

commentBody: My late wife died of cancer after a long period of illness. I stood by her side the entire time, and by so doing developed a deep and intimate rapport with her, the likes of which I could never have imagined before then. When my time comes, I would like to hold the hand of another special someone. Holding my own hand is a sad and depressing thought.
replies: [{'commentID': 103944603, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103944603, 'userID': 85521231, 'userDisplayName': 'Billadonna', 'userLocation': 'PA', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\\//>', 'commentBody': "@Peter I hear you. I lost mine almost three years ago after a long battle with cancer and all that goes with it. While I'm perfectly happy being single now in my 50s, the idea of facing old age and  death without someone who truly knows and loves me by my side is terrifying. I'm childless and have few relatives, most much older than I am. Friends are wonderful, but no friend is going to give up that much time and emotional energy when my time comes. Nor would I ask them to--having done all the intimate, caring things it takes to see someone through to their death, I know what an emotional and physical toll it takes. I wish us both good health and to die in our sleep in old age.", 'createDate': '1575391410', 'updateDate': '1576440468', 'approveDate': '1575391411', 'recommendations': 11, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103931196, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Peter', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103944603', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody: This makes a lot of sense. I would only add that we have different needs, and ways of expressing ourselves, at different ages. Having been a husband for many years, and raised a child, at this point in my life I find that friends and activities I care about are fulfilling for me. The tug of finding a new "one" to replace the one who is no longer there is like a sliver in the brain, especially when most of one's friends are still coupled. But being alone, and involved with life, is far preferable to coupling out of desperation, or loneliness. Knowing how to be a good partner to yourself is nearly as challenging as learning how to be a good partner in a marriage, I find. But worth it.

After being widowed for three years, I have established that being single is the healthiest life choice for me.  My husband gave me lots of freedom and space, and most males, in my experience need a lot more attention and control over me than I am willing to give.  I still love my husband very deeply and I talk to him every day.  The  love we shared is enough for this lifetime.  I have a close network of family and friends, and I am committed to deepening those relationships.  Being single is wonderful.

commentBody: It takes a lot of psychological strength to go it alone, to not succumb to the pressures of our couples' culture. I know from experience  that being alone and not lonely is possible. I also know from experience that you can find your soulmate and live very happily as a couple with the right person. My husband is so supportive and kind, sometimes I wonder if I'm dreaming. I have experienced the hell of being in a toxic relationship so I appreciate what I have found all the more, a healthy love with a man who truly wants me to be my own person. But  marriage and family is not for everyone. To be on your own, to choose singlehood and self partnering is the ultimate in a free society that values individualism.

I'm sure when you are young, rich, famous, and surrounded by sycophants the idea of "self-coupling" might make some sense. Let's see what happens as time goes on, show business is hard and full of illusions. What's leftover after the A list status is gone?

It seems a cold intellectual view to think we can all be islands unto ourselves. Especially considering the increased suicide rate in girls, seemingly in direct correlation with social media use and screen time, where insurmountable ideals like these (and others) may seem real and attainable.

Self-partnering on a journey of discovery with a rich social network of friends and family. Not so desolate or less desirous an outcome then one may imagine. Its not a nunnery or a hermitage constrained by rigid vows of self restraint. Nor a coupled path of monogamy like Ospreys.

Welcome to the world of experiential engagements kayaking In Mare Inventa.
Alice Walker wrote about this in her powerful essay Beauty: When the Other Dancer is the Self.
What has long perplexed me is how so many people, having failed to find "The One", settle for "Anyone".
Both are women. I wonder how many men would choose to “self-partner”.  If mostly women (which I suspect is the case), a good question might be: why?

While I am sure there are male-female partnerships that are rewarding to both in equal measure, I think the power imbalance between men and women that persists despite women’s progress in the work domain means that women find their relationships with men less satisfying than the other way around. commentBody:
I find this article sad. Yes, we should do all we can to be as kind, loving and fulfilling to ourselves as possible.

But to suggest that that is the same as finding a soul mate to experience life with seems ridiculous to me. I honestly don't know what percentage of people (single or married) achieve a true life partner, but I don't think that disparages the value of it.

And I suspect being rich and famous like Ms. Watson or Lizzo, makes it far easier to face life "alone" than it is for most of us.
replies: [{'commentID': 103943291, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103943291, 'userID': 46001542, 'userDisplayName': 'D Greitzer', 'userLocation': 'Ridgeway, ON', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\\//>', 'commentBody': '@Sparky The article does say that those who do find a suitable partner "hit the jackpot."  The author still understands the beauty of finding someone to share your journey of fulfillment.  The author is just pointing out that those who are not lucky enough to find such a partner can still have a happy and fulfilling life.  That\'s not sad; it\'s empowering.  It\'s saying that young people haven\'t failed if they haven\'t found their perfect mate; they don\'t have to settle just because society validates married people.  Single people might be doing what\'s best for them.', 'createDate': '1575388334', 'updateDate': '1575424379', 'approveDate': '1575388335', 'recommendations': 11, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103942799, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Sparky', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103943291', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody: Having enough fiscal resources to marry and maintain independence is increasingly difficult in this age of income inequality. Areas of the country that are economically disadvantaged (think red states) have lower rates of marriage simply because they don't have the money to be married. The emotional high of finding 'the one' does not always last.

“...make your life what it’s supposed to be.” This begs the question, who said your life was supposed to be a certain way? Is there an actual yardstick out there by which we’re supposed to measure ourselves? And if the yardstick only exists in our mind, what then? 

I’m all for individuation in the Jungian sense, but even he said that it never ends, that we’re always on the way to becoming something else. And certainly, he believed that you can only actualize certain parts of yourself in relationship with another human being. The contradiction here is that actualizing those parts of yourself in a relationship come from letting go of your ego concerns — not putting your needs ahead of your partner’s. And for most people, actual sacrifice for the good of another is definitely not what “life is supposed to be.” 

As Tibetan Buddhists say, the only true suffering comes from wishing exclusively for your own happiness, and the only happiness comes from wishing for the happiness of others. What better way to realize this than through relating deeply with another who challenges your own sense of entitlement?
At 65 and 35 years into a wonderful marriage I's say it's as much about luck as agency. Maybe more so.

Some valuable musings, but your early sentence -- "It just means that she is going on her journey of self-fulfillment and discovery alone" -- is off. 

EW and L are definitely not going it alone. As performers they are among the mostly highly network-dependent people out there. They are choosing to not have The One -- a Mr. or Ms. Right.  That should be ok.

A TED talk guru on this topic whose name I forget said, "I would recommend people spend less time looking for Mr. Right and more time being Mr. Right."

That seems like sound advice. Now if one wants to have kids -- a weighty decision given the state of the world -- sharing that life project (and workload and expense) with a co-parent seems like both a more fun and efficient approach than single-parenting.
Yup.  Didn't realize it until I was in my fifties, but with age comes wisdom.  Some get it earlier than the rest.

There is nothing more challenging than relationship. It is a real learning experience whatever happens within it ... and, with awareness, can be a great teacher in that it reveals our faults and our strengths as we move through life. Avoiding being in a relationship for self-righteous reasons is certainly one path; but the learning curve with “the other” is vastly more productive and, possibly more fun. Cutting off the possibility of relationship seems too hermetic to me.  One of my favorite “poems” by the Texan sculptor James Surls is this: “See a star, travel far. A Soul don’t live in a Mason Jar”.  Reach out with LOVE.
replies:
[{'commentID': 103943427, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103943427, 'userID': 98114157, 'userDisplayName': 'Henry Dickens', 'userLocation': 'San Francisco, CA', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': '@JAY 

Thanks Jay. Being in a relationship (and this can include friends and family) is about experiencing all the good of it: the affection, the love, and the care. But loved ones can also point out mistakes we keep missing or errors we cannot seem to overcome. We hope spouses and partners will do that. I am grateful for the close relationships I have and I certainly don't pretend that I can live without them. 

If we all took the time to write an "acknowledgements" page to our lives, it might be helpful to consider who one would name. 

The reality is, relationships (of any kind) is work. It is a matter of whether one wants to do the work or not. Self-work. Yes. But not exclusively.', 'createDate': '1575388655', 'updateDate': '1575388657', 'approveDate': '1575388657', 'recommendations': 0, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103939510, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'JAY', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103943427', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody:
There is clearly something missing in North American priorities.  In fact, there is something wanting through the Western world. There is something missing in many lives. We all seem to know it. Nobody seems to know exactly what it is.    Some people say it's good old-fashioned "family" values. Others say it's moral discipline that we lack and they demand tougher judges and longer prison sentences.   A few lament the demise of religion, patriotism and a respect of values in general.    

The truth of the matter is we may be suffering from what we have lost in his generation, we are also suffering from what has increased in it as well.    Everyone is scrambling to get more of something.  More status, more security, more power,  more things.   Narcissism consumes a person with self.  So absorbed in their own agenda they find it almost impossible to sustain emotional relationships with other people.   Self-coupling.   Being my own soul mate . . sounds like a plan.

I am single because I haven't found someone to share with that will create a relationship happy for both people.  Why get involved with the wrong person just to avoid being alone?  I have friends, work, my parents, my dog, etc.  I give to charity, I do nice things for other people.  I am part of my community.  Is it so important that I be coupled?
replies: [{'commentID': 103940135, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103940135, 'userID': 66341374, 'userDisplayName': 'Ronnie Ryan Love Coach', 'userLocation': 'New Haven', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\\//>', 'commentBody': "@Jenna of course you can be happy solo and that is a fine choice. I agree it's not easy to find the right partner. But as a love and dating coach my thought is, if you still want a relationship and feel you are missing out, then keep looking. This is about getting what you want - if you still want it. I firmly believe finding a good partner is possible. People find love every day. And if you don't want it - that's OK too.", 'createDate': '1575381667', 'updateDate': '1575483054', 'approveDate': '1575381668', 'recommendations': 6, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103938048, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Jenna', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103940135', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody:
Waddya know.  The end result of a world that gave us the 'me' generation:  Self-love taken to its penultimate destination.

In other words, "I am perfect.  I am the only one who's perfect.  Everyone else is imperfect.  At worst, they are impediments to my life's perfection; at best, their only purpose is to be supporting players in my life's reality."

commentBody:
Men in their 60s who are dating women in their 60s want to live with them but the women don't.
I would never marry again--I like me too much.
From the beginning of Marriage, women have been working for their "room and board" and no longer have to do that to survive.

I have felt this way for many years. It's almost embarrassing to say . . . I am the kind of person that I would like to hang out with. At 60, I find myself happy with who I am and my place in the world. While happiest alone, I am no recluse, and actually socialize more now than ever before. Dare I say it ? I am truly content in an unraveling world. Live each moment.

We each have to learn to live with ourselves before settling down with someone and if we do, that someone must allow us to continue the discovery of self and other. A healthy relationship is one in which both people can evolve on their own and of course together. It must be a lot harder for famous people to find the right person as star power is an unhealthy draw for some. Similarly I was always glad that I wasn’t a knock out because at least I knew I was not liked just for my looks!

Maslow was a social construct genius. If you apply his theoretical framework ,to each human ,the clarity of “survival of the fittest “is apparent. The theory allows therapists to find the developmental level their client has gotten stuck in. If abuse in a human life and fear of harm are introduced in infancy or childhood it causes the PTSD and struggles in normalcy we observe in our most conflicted in society. The task of senior citizens like me ,is the awareness of self actualization. Did I succeed in this life in all spheres of existence ? Did I cause joy or harm to those I love and cherish ? Did I achieve at each level of the Maslow hierarchy of human needs. If I did , Maslow would grade me as a successful human. It removes religion and social mores and values and gives us a solid core to measure. Erick Erickson and Maslow define human societies and achievement. Theories since just use these two guys premises and change the vernacular and pretend a new discovery of how humans behave. I smile at this. Nothing new under the sun. Margaret Mead was in their league too. I was exposed to Maslow et al in my Nursing program studies. Our “ nursing care plans “ built on these theories and those of nursing Leaders in the post war era of the 50’s to early 1970’s.
In the 1980’s new social constructs were studied. Chaos Theory was introduced when healthcare morphed into a Big Business as a human privilege instead of a human right .
The parallels to healthcare and marriage are apparent.

Narcissus, Mr. and Ms. will either enable or ignore the  other as their commitments let whither what remains of community, cooperation and idealism. Realism of expectations for one's soul mates is both righteous and intelligent but if that soul mate is oneself then an erosion of the soul seems inevitable. Being alone is not loneliness and being together is not an inoculation to loneliness but openness to another is the most curative meditation I have known.
